comments.commentBody: The government chose to bail out the banks instead of creating jobs. With so many people unemployed, or underemployed federal income tax revenue is sliding, helping to feed the deficits. If everybody who is underwater on their mortgage walks away, along with everyone who owes a big balance on a bank credit card, the government won't be able to bail the banks out a second time.

Pretty glib, Harry. Still trying to pass the buck for your own failures? You had 60 votes.... sorta...and had to resort to bribes and buying them to keep them in the fold. I don't think any of them had an" R" after their name, so how does "no" even come into play? Nelson was the only one smart enough to see that your abortion of a bill was wrong through and through, and opted out before he was in by getting a lifetime exemption from the unfunded mandates of the bill. Of course there were other perks scattered in there also..... by your hand, and at the behest of YOUR party.

So, NO, I don't believe you, NO you haven't any credibility, and NO, you can't pass the buck on this.

That much we KNOW!

The people who caused the problem were all fired. The politicians clearly never held a real job. This is like not paying the firemen who come to a burning house because the house is on fire while they're doing their jobs.

Think about it.

I think it would be very helpful and informative if the recipients of such bonuses were allowed air time on national television to explain to the rest of us why it is so important that they receive their exorbitant paychecks while so many others are losing their homes, going hungry, working long hours at minimum wage or not having jobs at all. I'm sure that once I understand their plight i'll be far more sympathetic.

Zapatero's economic policies (or rather the lack of them, when facing the crisis) have been a failure for the country, and he pretended a photo with Obama would keep him in power at ease for two or three more months.

We have a terrible unemployement here in Spain (20%), and what we need to do is focus on it, create jobs, redo our global economy and strategy, and extend a culture of work that the social-democracy not always can develop.

Obama's snub is a refreshing one to understand that Spain's future, and Europe's, should be a hard-working one, a global one, and a liberal one. Our national identities are a heavy load for many of us.

I'm happy anyway some of you disagree with the manners, he could have write a personal note, don't he?

You do however well focusing on the problems the States are facing, as well as regarding the Pacific.

Come to Madrid and take tortilla and chatos (half glass of red wine)!
Europe needs to just chill for a while. Theres plenty of international cooperation between us and them as it is. They are so clingy.

Since he has apologized to everyone and anyone that will listen to him for the supposed wrongs that our nation has committed, I imagine that he will once again apologize. I'm quite sure that the previous administration must have had something to do with this scheduling mix-up!! Maybe Samuel Alito and John Roberts caused this to happen? Better start downloading those inspiring speeches to those Ipods and send them to disgruntled European leaders!!!!
Who cares? His domestic policy is run by Goldman Sachs and his foreign policy by AIPAC. All coordinated by his wonderful Chief of Staff, an ex-IDF soldier, can you imagine?

I am really upset what this world is coming. I don't see why it matters what your sexual orientation is. People join the military to fight for us not to worry about who likes what, that is his/her personal business. By ending this law, they are creating a bunch of unneeded drama. These soldiers out here should not have to worry about who's gay or not. This is just rediculous!

Man, I was in a zone tonight, rare sub-four-minute Wednesday, and equally rare sub-Amy-Reynaldo time. (By the transitive property, also beat ihavefourdogs.) All those cliches rolled off the keyboard after a mere two and a half years of parenthood. Sigh!

Beautiful Entries: theme entries, bien sur, plus BUGGY, YUKS, BOBBY, AZURE, SKY HOOK, NO DUH, SEE-THRU, REQUITE, AD WAR*

Clever Clues: "Stallion-to-be," "Seasoning for pommes frites," "All-nighter site, perhaps"

Misdirection: thinking clothes not TV programs for "Put on," boat not pitcher for "Vessel," body of water not bowl for "basin"

Errors: ACTA for ACTO

New Words (well, abbreviations anyway): CARB (standing for CARBuretor, I presume, not CARBohydrate!), INQ. (I think it's INQuest, Jim)

New Facts About Old Words: Kirk's birthplace

Wikipedia Worthy: "Psycho," rappers Dr. DRE and JAY-Z (bracing to hear from the anti-rap contingent, which I'll wager has a great deal of overlap with the anti-Simpsons contingent), BEA Benaderet*, Newcastle Upon TYNE, George ELIOT, YALU River, Jan van EYCK, ILYA Kovalchuk, Frederik POHL, YAO Ming, JEANE Dixon, ISERE, John ROLFE*, ERIK Estrada

Crosswordese: ENOS (??/172), the crossword puzzle's favorite grandson of Adam and Eve (where did his mom come from again?!), also clued as a '40s Cardinal, 1961 space chimp, or '80s Hazzard County deputy; ALOU (89), been there, done that; ERGS (54), the crossword puzzle's favorite unit in the cgs (as opposed to mks) metric system, even more popular in the singular (102); TRON (??/82), the crossword puzzle's favorite bad '80s movie; EDY'S (42), the crossword puzzle's favorite brand of ice cream, less popular in the singular (8/9)

I learned ROWEL from crosswords (today's is the ninth entry in Jim's database) but ISERE from some time in Grenoble.  Surprisingly, today's is appearance #48 in the Shortz era.  That would seem to make it common crosswordese at worst, a few notches up from obscure.  The 1992 Albertville Olympics had a number of events at Val d'Isère, which could help solvers.  In any case, with four vowels and an S, #48 won't be the last.

I was a little surprised by JAYZ being clued by one particular song, no matter now popular. Earlier puzzles have clued him more in his role as a tycoon. Maybe next time he'll get clued as "Husband of..." Here's the song, anyway:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o_gt8W9D2II

Stick around for the first minute, and then the singing starts. What can I tell you, I like it.
This is simply an humongous demonstration of irresponsible behavior.

I did a pretty quick run-through of this puzzle, pausing only over 14A, 18A (I started with PRIX), 47A (of course), 50A, 26D (ACTA), and 50D, but the crosswords took care of all of these.

Regarding 1A, I thought the BOBBY was a London figure, and that his counterparts in the hinterlands--e.g., Coventry, were just called constables. I see the pull of the alliteration, but is it right?
Maybe there was some Freudian misread on my part, but I thought this post's title read, "Rex Ryan is Fined for Obese Gesture."
...  And then Gregg Williams challenged Rex Ryan to a cage match.

I like the approach. You have to hit Manning. There is a direct hits-to-"Manning face" ratio.

I also like the idea of NFL football in the playoffs being like playoffs in other sports. In the NHL and even the NBA the play gets more physical in the playoffs, the refs swallow the whistle a bit more. I think the same should be done in the NFL. The last thing I want to see is a 15-yard penalty because Brees' head fell into Robert Mathis' hand.

Also, I haven't seen an NFL playoff game this year that is as violent as Big East Basketball.

Hyderabad is famous for Hyderabadi Biryani and deserts like "khubani-ka-meeta" and "double-ka-meeta"these are the places to look for:

1) Shadab Hotel
2) Paradise
3) Bawarchi
4) Cafe Bahar
5) Alpha cafe
6) Blue Fox
7) Hyderabad House
8) Hotel Sohail

These are not star hotels but they serve you the true traditional Hyderabad dishes.The other traditional Indian dishes are more or less same in any restaurant across the city.

My father-in-law: You wait until the last second when you don't have a minute to spare.

(Probably not a Malaprop; it's a whazzit.)

Who can beat "De'ja vu all over again"?

Meanwhile, my little brother wanted to go to Yankee Studayum

and my father-in-law objected because it meant crossing the Frog's Neck Bridge.

we would have to cross the Frog's Neck Bridge

Years ago one of my high school students was writing a very personal essay in which he talked about his and his girlfriend's sexual relationship.  However, he reassured me that they were being cautious: they were using condiments. I still to this day picture them smeared in mustard and ketchup. Don't know if pregnancy ever occurred, but they must have had to bathe frequently!

234 Jed Salt Lake City:

Neither chop or chopped SUEY . .If quoting any borscht-belt comedian,
it ought to be: Chopped Liver.

Thought you'd be interested to know.
I found today's Idea too hard to think about and still have nothing to say.

"- even totally nonsubstantive changes like writing it in a cleaner font or making it rhyme or simply repeating it - can alter people’s judgment..."

The nonsubstantive rhyme
(and is there any other kind)
is such a waste of time
-- for so much influence on the mind.

Maybe this also explains how Bush got elected twice.

His name is easy to spell.

W.
